stories.text:
I am considering building an app for gamers to compete with each other in a single-player game. The app does not interact with the game's source code in any way - it is entirely separate. I plan to monetize the app.

The game's EULA forbids any derivative works. I've been googling a lot and it seems that some derivative works are considered 'fair use' - for example, game-related content from creators on youtube and twitch. Is my app going to be considered 'fair use' too?

Is there any copyright lawyer who could help me understand if my app is going to infringe the game's copyright?

Thanks in advance!!!
stories.title: Ask HN: Pro bono advice from copyright lawyer?

stories.text:
This is the MVP of a web app I made to help founders start successful companies. The idea is to provide tools to assist founders, such as: - Business model development - Recommendations based on your current business context and your own role in it - Add recommendations as tasks

There are more features in the works too, such as automated answering of common questions. I also want to add far more recommendations than are currently available.

The tech stack is: - Flutter (front-end) - Nim (back-end) - PostgreSQL (DB)

The UI is actually written on the back-end in Nim, and rendered by Flutter. I'm planning to make this tech available as Open Source, and you can join a wait-list if interested: https://nexusdev.tools/

Feedback on CxO Industries, but also the tech behind it, is welcome.
